title: 103_hr2415
content: The Act may be cited as the "Reserve Account for Administrative Savings Act of 1993". Government Efficiency Reserve Accounts are established. The "Reserve Account for Administrative Savings Act of 1993" establishes Government Efficiency Reserve Accounts. Subchapter II of chapter 15 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include a special rule for apportioning salaries and expenses within an appropriation. Appropriations for salaries and expenses must be apportioned as necessary, with a reserve of 5% of the previous fiscal year's expenses established, unless the current appropriation is less. The "Reserve Account for Administrative Savings Act of 1993" establishes Government Efficiency Reserve Accounts. Appropriations for salaries and expenses must be apportioned as necessary, with a reserve of 5% of the previous fiscal year's expenses established, unless the current appropriation is less. Each agency head with such appropriations must make recommendations for changes within 60 days of the fiscal year's start. The "Reserve Account for Administrative Savings Act of 1993" establishes Government Efficiency Reserve Accounts for agencies to recommend changes in operations to reduce salaries and expenditures without affecting programs. The President's budget submission must include recommendations on releasing reserved funds, reducing program levels, or requesting supplemental appropriations. The "Reserve Account for Administrative Savings Act of 1993" allows for supplemental appropriations to be offset by rescissions of funds held in reserve. If the President recommends releasing funds held in reserve for any agency, a bill must be included to enact the release. Any funds held in reserve at the end of a fiscal year are rescinded and returned to the Treasury unless a law requires their release. Additionally, a fast-track supplemental appropriation can be made up to the aggregate amount rescinded. Before the close of the second legislative day after receiving a special message under section 1520(e), the majority or minority leader of the House of Representatives must introduce the draft bill. If not introduced, any member can do so on the third legislative day. The bill will be referred to the House Committee on Appropriations and must be reported within seven legislative days. During consideration under this subsection, any Member of the House of Representatives may move to strike any provision of the bill or offer an amendment to reduce any amount proposed to be released. A vote on final passage of the bill shall be taken in the House of Representatives on or before the close of the 10th legislative day of that House after the date of the introduction of the bill. If the bill is passed, it shall be engrossed, certified, and transmitted to the Senate within one calendar day. The bill is passed under this section with specific rules for debate and decision-making in the House of Representatives. Motion to proceed is privileged and not debatable, debate is limited to 4 hours, and appeals are decided without debate. The bill under this section is decided without debate, governed by House rules. In the Senate, the bill is referred to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report on it within seven days. Senators can propose amendments to reduce proposed amounts. The Senate must vote on final passage of a bill within 10 legislative days. Debate on the bill and related motions in the Senate cannot exceed 10 hours. Debate in the Senate on any debatable motion or appeal in connection with a bill under this section shall be limited to 1 hour, equally divided between the mover and the manager of the bill. Additional time can be allotted by the leaders. A motion to further limit debate on a bill under this subsection is not debatable. Under this section, no amendments are allowed except to strike a provision or reduce a proposed amount. Dividing the question or suspending this rule is not permitted. Budget authority proposed for restoration must be available for obligation the day after the bill is transmitted to Congress. The section specifies that budget authority proposed for restoration must be available for obligation the day after the bill is enacted into law, unless rescinded. The term "legislative day" is defined as any day when either House of Congress is in session. The amendments made by this Act apply to fiscal years 1994-1998 and expire after September 30, 1998.
